cards.XSS: Use a website a user trusts to execute malicious code.
cards.Rainbow tables: Giant hashtables of precalculated hashes, usualy MD5
cards.Mandatory Access Control: The system speficies which subject can access specific data objects.
cards.OWASP top 10: Injection, weak authentication, XSS, IDOR, Security misconf, Sensetive data exposure, Top level access control, CSRF, Known vulnerabilities, Unvalidated redirects and forwards.
cards.Authentication: Prove that you are the identity you say you are.
cards.Risk management framework: Categorize, Select, Implement, Assess, Authorize, Monitor
cards.Multilevel security: Different people can access different stuff.
cards.Security theater: Security theater is the practice of investing in countermeasures intended to provide the feeling of improved security while doing little or nothing to actually achieve it
cards.OpenSAMM: Compare your security practices against best practice.
cards.Needham-Schroeder: Like Kerberos, but uses nounces instead of timestamps.
cards.Principle of least privilege: Processes should only be able to access exactly what they need, nothing more.
cards.Attack vector: Path or means by which a hacker (or cracker) can gain access to a computer or network server
cards.Attack surface: Every surface of an application which can be used for a potential attack.
cards.Threat modeling process: Identify critical assets, Decompose the system, Identify possible points of attack, Identify threats, Categorise/prioritise the threats, Mitigate.
cards.Biba: A security model that values integrity, no read down, no write up.
cards.Sandboxing: Running stuff in a seperate container.
cards.Kerberos: Network auth protocol, auth over non-secure network. Both client and server identifies eachother. Protect against eavesdropping and replay attack, not timing.
cards.Misuse case: Describes the process of executing a malicious act against a system, while use case can be used to describe any action taken by the system.
cards.Framework: Politcy, what you want to achive, Mechanism, how you will implement, Assurance, the amount of trust on one mech, Incentive, the motive for people to do job properly.
cards.Timing attack: Take the time before a prompt that validates a string cancel, this way you can find out how long it takes for a password to fail.
cards.The Chineese wall: A security model where read/write access to files is governed by membership of data in conflict-of-interest classes and datasets. This is the basic model used to provide both privacy and integrity for data.
cards.One-way function: Passwords should be encrypted/hashed one way, they should not be reversible.
cards.Race conditions: Two people trying to change something at the sametime, which will result in one getting the wrong value.
cards.Eavesdropping: Offer free WiFi to harvest passwords and other data.
cards.High-water-mark: Under high-water mark, any object less than the user's security level can be opened, but the object is relabeled to reflect the highest security level currently open. Hence the name.
cards.Phishing: Try to trick someone in to a false website to get their information.
cards.Groups vs roles ACL: A group is a list of principals, a role is one or more principals that a role may use.
cards.HTTP Methods: GET, POST, PUT, DELETE, TRACE, HEAD, OPTIONS, CONNECT
cards.One-time pad: Encryption technique that encrypts plaintext paired with a random secret key.
cards.Zero-day vulnerability: A vulnerability that currently has no fix.
cards.CSRF: Trick a user to click a link which executes stuff on a different site. A mail.
cards.Attack tree: A tree which describes the current threats to a system.
cards.Discretionary Access Control: Unix file model, access control is controlled by the owner of the object.
cards.Pretexting: False motive, Pretending to be somebody you are not, to get something you probably shouldnt have, to use in a way that is probably wrong
cards.Bell LaPadula: A security model that values confidentiality, no read up, no write down.
cards.The lattice model: MAC, Subject is only allowed to access an object if he has greater or equal sec level than the object.
cards.BSIMM: Compare your security practice against other companies
cards.Captcha: Completely Automated Public Turing test to tell Computers and Humans Apart
cards.SQL injection: Using poorly sanitized inputfields to inject SQL code to get more information than you should.
cards.Caprass: Code review, Architectural risk, Penetration test, Risk-based security tests, Abuse cases, security requirements, security operations
cards.7 touchpoints: Code review, Architectural risk, Penetration test, Risk-based security tests, Abuse cases, security requirements, security operations
cards.Proof carrying code: Code that carries a proof that it will not violate local security policy.
cards.DoS: Make a service unavailable by overloading the servers or network.
cards.Two-factor authentication: Use two different things to authenticate you, usualy something you have and something you know.
